title: German, Czech and Italian politicians back calls for UK to cough up £50bn Brexit bill
text:
German, Czech and Italian politicians back calls for UK to cough up £50bn Brexit bill German, Czech and Italian politicians back calls for UK to cough up £50bn Brexit bill EU nations are standing firm in their calls for Britain to agree a £50billion Brexit bill BEFORE talks on the UK's divorce from Brussels can even begin. PUBLISHED: 20:19, Fri, Feb 24, 2017 | UPDATED: 20:29, Fri, Feb 24, 2017 GETTY Jean-Claude Juncker wants Britain to agree a 'hefty" divorce settlement before talks begin 
Several member states, including Germany, Italy, France and the Czech Republic, are demanding the eye-watering figure is agreed before discussions over Britain's future relationship with the EU start. 
With Prime Minister Theresa May hoping to trigger Article 50 next month, Brexit negotiators on both sides are getting ready to battle over what could be a bitter and acrimonious split. 
And high on the list of demands from the European Commission is that Britain's settles outstanding payments for EU projects it had committed to before the referendum vote on June 23 last year. 
Some forecasters have put the bill at around €60bn, or £50bn. Related articles Lord Bird: I ‘bottled’ backing Brexit due to Project Fear 
Earlier this week, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker insisted the UK faced a “salty" bill - the French slang for pricey - for leaving the Brussels. 
And he reiterated that meaningful talks about the rights of EU citizens living in the UK and Brits living in Europe could only begin once the fee to leave the bloc had been agreed. 
Mr Juncker's call was backed by politicians in France, Germany, Italy and the Czech republic. 
Austrian Chancellor Christian Kern also warned that Britain could not be "better off" than the remaining 27 EU nations following Brexit , but said he was more concerned with agreeing the rights of EU nationals first. 
There are concerns within Brussels, however, that taking such a hardline stance so early on will only anger Mrs May and MPs. 
According to the Guardian, a memo from European parliament officials to the economic and monetary affairs committee said the strategy "could prove to be risky as it might cause backlash by the UK during negotiations". 
Theresa May has previously said she is prepared to walk away from the EU negotiating table if a deal that benefitted Britain could not be reached. 
On the opposite side, EU Brexit negotiator Guy Verhofstadt has stated that no country wishing to cancel its membership could expect a deal that left them better off out than in the club. Related articles
